<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Recent Accounting Pronouncements</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In July&nbsp;2006, the FASB issued FASB Interpretation No.&nbsp;48, <I>&#147;Accounting for Uncertainty in Income
Taxes &#150; an Interpretation of FASB Statement No.&nbsp;109&#148; </I>(&#147;FIN 48&#148;), which clarifies the accounting for
uncertainty in tax positions. FIN 48 requires that AirNet recognize in its financial statements
the impact of a tax position based on the technical merits of the position. FIN 48 also requires
additional disclosures about unrecognized tax benefits associated with uncertain income tax
positions and a reconciliation of the change in the unrecognized benefit. In addition, FIN 48
requires interest to be recognized on the full amount of deferred benefits for uncertain tax
positions. FIN 48 is effective for fiscal years beginning after December&nbsp;15, 2006, with the
cumulative effect of the change in accounting principle recorded as an adjustment to opening
retained earnings. AirNet continues to evaluate the impact of FIN 48 on AirNet&#146;s consolidated
financial statements. As of the date of this Annual Report on Form 10-K, AirNet has not fully
competed its assessment upon adoption of this standard; however, AirNet does not expect the impact
to be significant, if any.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In September&nbsp;2006, the Securities and Exchange Commission issued Staff Accounting Bulletin No.&nbsp;108<I>,
&#147;Considering the Effects of Prior Year Misstatements When Quantifying Misstatements in Current Year
Financial Statements&#148; </I>(&#147;SAB 108&#148;). SAB 108 provides guidance on how the effects of the carryover
or reversal of prior year misstatements should be considered in quantifying a current year
misstatement. The guidance is applicable for fiscal years ending after November&nbsp;15, 2006. AirNet
has evaluated the guidance provided in SAB 108 and has determined that it will not have a
significant impact on the determination or reporting of AirNet&#146;s financial results.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Supplemental Cash Flow Data</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Cash paid for interest was $1,636,000, $1,913,000, and $1,287,000 for the years ended December&nbsp;31,
2006, 2005, and 2004, respectively. During the year ended December&nbsp;31, 2005, AirNet capitalized
approximately $300,000 in interest
related to the construction of its new Rickenbacker office and hangar facility. AirNet paid
$5,575,000, $265,000, and $208,000 and received $1,821,000, $39,000, and $62,000 for the years
ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005, and 2004, respectively, related to income taxes.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>2. Impairment of Property and Equipment and Goodwill</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">AirNet recognizes impairment losses on long-lived assets in accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;144,
<I>&#147;Accounting for the Impairment or Disposal of Long-Lived Assets&#148; </I>(&#147;SFAS No.&nbsp;144&#148;). AirNet
recognizes impairment losses on long-lived assets when events
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->45<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">or changes in circumstances indicate, in management&#146;s judgment, that AirNet&#146;s assets might be
impaired and the undiscounted cash flows estimated to be generated by those assets are less than
the carrying value of those assets. The carrying value of the assets not recoverable is reduced to
estimated fair market value if lower than carrying value. In determining the estimated fair market
value of the assets, AirNet considers information provided by third party valuation firms retained
to assist AirNet in completing its analysis, published market data, recent transactions involving
sales of similar assets and, at September&nbsp;30, 2005, the letter of intent for the sale of AirNet
that was announced on October&nbsp;26, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><U>2006 Asset Impairment Charge</U>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">AirNet&#146;s cargo airline was originally designed, and continues to operate, primarily to meet the
needs of Bank Services customers. As a result of accelerating trends in the implementation of
electronic payment alternatives and electronic alternatives to the physical movement of cancelled
checks, as of September&nbsp;30, 2006, AirNet evaluated for impairment the long-lived assets used in its
airline operations, consisting primarily of aircraft, aircraft parts and its airport hangar and
office facility located at Rickenbacker International Airport (the &#147;Rickenbacker Facility&#148;). The
undiscounted cash flows estimated to be generated by those assets including disposal values were
less than the related carrying values and therefore, pursuant to the requirements of SFAS No.&nbsp;144,
the estimated fair values of these assets were compared to carrying value and the carrying values
were reduced by a $24.6&nbsp;million non-cash impairment charge. As a result of AirNet&#146;s evaluation of
the required valuation allowance for deferred tax assets, no tax benefit was recognized related to
this impairment charge as described in Note 8 below.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The determination of undiscounted cash flows involves estimates of future cash flows, revenues,
operating expenses and disposal values. The projections of these amounts represent management&#146;s
best estimates at the time of the review. Management&#146;s estimates are significantly affected by the
continuing uncertainty of the timing and rate of decline in Bank Services revenues that are being
impacted by the implementation of electronic alternatives to the physical movement of cancelled
checks and AirNet&#146;s potential to grow other lines of cargo business as alternative sources of
revenues. AirNet will continue to explore cost saving initiatives and alternative sources of
revenue; however, in accordance with the provisions of SFAS No.&nbsp;144, until such strategies are
developed, AirNet has assigned minimal probabilities to those strategies in AirNet&#146;s determination
of future undiscounted cash flows. In the absence of additional cost saving initiatives or
alternative sources of revenue, it is likely that future determinations of estimated cash flows
will be less than the carrying value of AirNet&#146;s long-lived assets. As a result, AirNet will be
required to monitor the carrying value of its long-lived assets relative to estimated fair values
in future periods.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The 2006 asset impairment charge was based on a range of estimated fair values provided by third
party appraisal firms. The range of appraised fair values related to AirNet&#146;s long-lived assets
was approximately $49.7&nbsp;million to $27.7&nbsp;million reflecting different market factors, holding
periods and possible asset disposition scenarios that potentially could be elected by AirNet as it
evaluates its strategies in response to the current business environment. Because of the current
uncertainties in the business environment, management determined that the low end of the range of
fair values was the appropriate estimate of fair value at September&nbsp;30, 2006 and wrote down the
carrying value of AirNet&#146;s long-lived assets to approximately $27.7&nbsp;million. The determination of
the adjusted carrying value is a management estimate based upon the third party appraisals and the
subjective factors discussed above. It is possible that the future sales of assets, if any, could
be greater than or less than current carrying values. Further, if management uses different
assumptions or estimates in the future or if conditions exist in future periods that are different
than those anticipated, additional impairment charges may be required.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><U>2005 Asset Impairment Charge</U>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">AirNet also recorded an impairment charge as of September&nbsp;30, 2005. On October&nbsp;26, 2005, AirNet
announced that it had entered into a letter of intent for its sale in a going private transaction
at $4.55 per share. Since the price per share in the letter of intent was less than AirNet&#146;s then
net book value per share, AirNet performed the impairment tests required by SFAS No.&nbsp;144 for the
quarter ended September&nbsp;30, 2005 and concluded that its long-lived assets used in its Bank Services
and Express Services operations were impaired. Accordingly, a non-cash charge of $16.1&nbsp;million
($10.0&nbsp;million net of tax) was recorded as of September&nbsp;30, 2005. The impairment charge was based
upon the estimated fair values of the long-lived assets in AirNet&#146;s airline operations derived from
published sources, information provided by a third party valuation firm retained to assist AirNet
in completing its analysis, and the discount inherent in the price per share set forth in the
letter of intent.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><U>2004 Asset Impairment Charge</U>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">AirNet&#146;s long-lived assets used in its cargo operations, consisting primarily of aircraft and spare
parts, were also determined to be impaired as of September&nbsp;30, 2004. This determination was made
as a result of industry trends in the adoption of electronic payment alternatives and evolving
electronic alternatives to the physical movement of cancelled checks at a more rapid pace than
previously anticipated by the industry. AirNet determined that its airline capacity would exceed
future demand, which created an impairment of the aircraft and related assets. The impairment also
reflected the overall decline in the market values of the aircraft in its cargo fleet which had not
recovered as in previous economic cycles. AirNet determined that the expected future undiscounted
cash flows from its assets used in its cargo operations were less than the
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->46<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">carrying value of those assets and were impaired. Accordingly, a non-cash impairment charge of
$43.0&nbsp;million ($31.0&nbsp;million net of tax) was recorded as of September&nbsp;30, 2004, using estimated
aircraft fair values. The aircraft fair values used for this purpose were based upon published
market sources as of September&nbsp;30, 2004, which were also used under AirNet&#146;s Amended Credit
Agreement described in Note 4 below.<BR><BR>
Under SFAS No.&nbsp;142, AirNet evaluates its goodwill for impairment annually, or more frequently if
changes in circumstances indicate impairment may have occurred sooner. At September&nbsp;30, 2004,
AirNet determined that as a result of the impairment of its long-lived assets used in its Bank
Services and Express Services operations, the remaining goodwill assigned to the cargo operations
should be evaluated for potential impairment. AirNet evaluated the fair value of its goodwill
related to its Bank Services and Express Services operations based upon a discounted future cash
flow analysis. As a result of the impairment test, AirNet determined that its goodwill was
impaired and, accordingly, a non-cash impairment charge of $4.0&nbsp;million was recorded at September
30, 2004. There was no goodwill recorded at December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>3. Discontinued Operations</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On July&nbsp;26, 2006, AirNet, Jetride, and Pinnacle Air, LLC (&#147;Pinnacle&#148;) entered into a purchase
agreement regarding the sale of Jetride&#146;s passenger charter business to Pinnacle (the &#147;Purchase
Agreement&#148;). The sale was completed on September&nbsp;26, 2006. The purchase price was $41.0&nbsp;million
in cash, of which $40.0&nbsp;million was consideration for the sale of nine company-owned aircraft and
related engine maintenance programs and $1.0&nbsp;million was consideration for the sale of all of the
outstanding capital stock of a newly-created subsidiary of Jetride, also called Jetride, Inc. (&#147;New
Jetride&#148;). Upon completion of the sale transaction, Jetride amended its articles of incorporation
to change its name to 7250 STARCHECK, INC. Of the total consideration, $40.0&nbsp;million was paid at
closing and $1.0&nbsp;million was paid into escrow to cover indemnification claims which may be made by
Pinnacle for up to eighteen months after the closing. To the extent the escrow amount is not used
to satisfy indemnification claims, the escrow amount is to be released to AirNet in two
installments approximately six and twelve months after the closing. In March&nbsp;2007, $500,000 of the
escrowed amount was released to AirNet. AirNet retained the net working capital of the Jetride
passenger charter business, which was approximately $2.2&nbsp;million as of the closing date. In
connection with the closing of the sale transaction, Jetride repaid in full six term loans which
had been secured by aircraft used in Jetride&#146;s passenger charter business. The aggregate principal
amount of the loans repaid was approximately $28.2&nbsp;million plus accrued interest and early
termination prepayment penalties of approximately $0.3&nbsp;million through the repayment date.
Following repayment of Jetride&#146;s loans and expenses related to the transaction, AirNet used the
remaining sale proceeds to further reduce debt outstanding under AirNet&#146;s secured revolving credit
facility. AirNet&#146;s lenders under the secured revolving credit facility had consented to the sale
of the Jetride passenger charter business and the various transactions necessary to complete the
sale.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In accordance with SFAS No.&nbsp;144, AirNet has classified the assets and liabilities of Passenger
Charter Services as assets and liabilities related to discontinued operations and presented this
operating segment&#146;s results of operations as discontinued operations for all periods presented. As
a result of the disposition of Passenger Charter Services, AirNet has only one reportable segment.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Revenues from Passenger Charter Services, included in discontinued operations, were approximately
$16.9&nbsp;million, $29.5&nbsp;million and $18.5&nbsp;million for 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. Income from
discontinued operations before income taxes for 2006, 2005 and 2004 was approximately $0.1&nbsp;million,
$0.8&nbsp;million and $1.6&nbsp;million, respectively. Included in the 2006 income from discontinued
operations before income taxes is a pre-tax gain of approximately $1.0&nbsp;million, which is net of
approximately $1.0&nbsp;million of investment banking and legal fees associated with the sale of
Jetride.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In February&nbsp;2006, AirNet decided to market for sale all nine of the Cessna 310 Piston cargo
aircraft as a result of the need to reduce its airline capacity and operating costs. At that date,
AirNet determined that the plan of sale criteria of SFAS No.&nbsp;144 had been met. The carrying value
of the assets was determined to approximate the estimated fair value less cost to sell, based on
recent aircraft appraisals. The carrying value of the aircraft approximates $0.3&nbsp;million, and is
classified in &#147;Assets held for sale&#148; in the Consolidated Balance Sheet. In November&nbsp;2006, AirNet
entered into an agreement to sell all nine of its Cessna 310 aircraft for approximately $0.4
million. AirNet delivered six aircraft in the first quarter of 2007 and expects to deliver the
three remaining aircraft in April of 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>4. Notes Payable</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">AirNet had borrowings as follows at December&nbsp;31:

<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Revolving Credit Facility &#150; 2002 through 2006</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In September&nbsp;2002, AirNet entered into a $35.0&nbsp;million unsecured revolving credit facility and a
five-year $20.0&nbsp;million unsecured term loan (collectively, the &#147;Credit Agreement&#148;). The revolving
credit facility under the Credit Agreement was originally scheduled to expire on September&nbsp;30, 2005
and the secured term loan was to mature on September&nbsp;30, 2007.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On May&nbsp;28, 2004, AirNet and its lenders amended the terms and conditions of the Credit Agreement
(the &#147;Amended Credit Agreement&#148;). The Amended Credit Agreement was further amended by the First,
Second, Third, Fourth and Fifth Change in Terms Agreements, as described below. The Amended Credit
Agreement was secured by a first lien on all of the property of AirNet and its subsidiaries, other
than any interest in real estate and certain excluded fixed assets. AirNet also pledged the stock
and interests of its subsidiaries to secure the loans under the Amended Credit Agreement, and each
of AirNet&#146;s subsidiaries guaranteed AirNet&#146;s obligations under the Amended Credit Agreement. The
Amended Credit Agreement also contained certain financial covenants that require AirNet to maintain
a minimum consolidated tangible net worth and to not exceed certain fixed charge coverage and
leverage ratios specified in the Amended Credit Agreement.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Amended Credit Agreement initially provided for a secured revolving credit facility of up to
$35.0&nbsp;million and a secured term loan in the aggregate amount of $14.0&nbsp;million. The amount of
revolving loans available under the Amended Credit Agreement was limited to a borrowing base equal
to the aggregate of 80% of eligible accounts receivable, plus 50% of eligible aircraft parts, plus
70% of the market value of certain fixed assets, reduced by the aggregate amount of AirNet&#146;s
outstanding letters of credit. The Amended Credit Agreement bore interest, at AirNet&#146;s option, at
(a)&nbsp;a fixed rate equal to LIBOR plus a margin determined by AirNet&#146;s leverage ratio as defined in
the Amended Credit Agreement, or (b)&nbsp;a floating rate based on the greater of (i)&nbsp;the prime rate
established by The Huntington National Bank from time to time plus a margin determined by AirNet&#146;s
leverage ratio or (ii)&nbsp;the sum of 0.5% plus the federal funds rate in effect from time to time plus
a margin determined by AirNet&#146;s leverage ratio.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Amended Credit Facility was amended in September&nbsp;2004, March&nbsp;2005, November&nbsp;2005, March&nbsp;2006
and September&nbsp;2006. The above amendments to the Amended Credit Facility were reflected,
respectively, in the &#147;First Change in Terms Agreement&#148;, the &#147;Second Change in Terms Agreement&#148; ,
the &#147;Third Change in Terms Agreement&#148;, the &#147;Fourth Change in Terms Agreement&#148; and the &#147;Fifth Change
in Terms Agreement&#148;.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">As a result of the impairment charges recorded by AirNet in September&nbsp;2004, September&nbsp;2005 and
September&nbsp;2006, AirNet was not in compliance with certain terms and conditions of the Amended
Credit Facility, including the fixed charge coverage ratio, the leverage ratio and the minimum
consolidated tangible net worth requirement. The First, Third and Fifth Change in Terms Agreements
modified certain financial covenants contained in the Amended Credit Facility in such a manner
that, on a going-forward basis, the impairment charges, in and of themselves, would not cause a
default of these financial covenants in the future. At the same time that the First, Third and
Fifth Change in Terms Agreements were entered into, AirNet and its lenders executed a waiver of any
defaults or potential defaults under the Amended Credit Agreement which occurred, or may have
occurred, as a result of AirNet&#146;s failure to comply with the above financial covenants due to the
various impairment charges.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In addition to the amendments made to the Amended Credit Facility to bring the financial covenants
into compliance after the impairment charges recorded in 2004, 2005 and 2006, the Amended Credit
Facility was amended on several occasions to modify other terms and conditions of the Amended
Credit Facility. The Second Change in Terms Agreement amended the Amended Credit Facility to
reflect that AirNet had prepaid in full the remaining $11.0&nbsp;million balance outstanding on its
secured term loan. In addition, the Second Change in Terms Agreement reduced the secured revolving
credit facility from $35.0&nbsp;million to $30.0&nbsp;million. The Second Change in Terms Agreement also
extended the term of the Amended Credit Facility from September&nbsp;30, 2005 to October&nbsp;15, 2006. The
Fourth Change in Terms Agreement further extended the term of the Amended Credit Agreement from
October&nbsp;15, 2006 to October&nbsp;15, 2007 and modified the
calculation of the borrowing base. The Fifth Change in Terms Agreement reduced the amount of
the secured revolving credit facility from $25&nbsp;million to $15&nbsp;million.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, there was no amount outstanding under the Amended Credit Agreement. As of
December&nbsp;31, 2006, AirNet had $1.0&nbsp;million in letters of credit outstanding related to insurance
programs, which reduced the amount available under the revolving credit facility. As of December
31, 2006, AirNet had $14.0&nbsp;million available to borrow under its secured revolving credit facility
under the Amended Credit Agreement.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><I>Revolving
Credit Facility &#150; Second Amended Credit Agreement &#151; March 29, 2007</I>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On March&nbsp;29, 2007, AirNet and its lender (The Huntington National Bank) amended and restated the
terms and conditions of the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement dated as of May&nbsp;28, 2004, among
The Huntington National Bank and Bank One, N.A., as lenders, and AirNet, as borrower (as amended
and restated, the &#147;Amended Credit Agreement&#148;) by entering into a Second Amended and Restated Credit
Agreement (the &#147;Second Amended Credit Agreement&#148;). The following description of the Second Amended
Credit Agreement is qualified in its entirety by reference to the Second Amended Credit Agreement.
The Second Amended Credit Agreement provides for a $15.0&nbsp;million secured revolving credit facility
and expires on October&nbsp;15, 2008. The Second Amended Credit Agreement is secured by a first
priority lien on all of the property of AirNet, other than any interest in real estate and certain
excluded fixed assets. The stock and interests of AirNet&#146;s subsidiaries continue to be pledged to
secure the loans under the Second Amended Credit Agreement, and each of AirNet&#146;s subsidiaries
continues to guarantee AirNet&#146;s obligations under the Second Amended Credit Agreement under a
Consent and Agreement of Guarantors.
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->48<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">




<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The amount of revolving loans available under the Second Amended Credit Agreement is limited to a
borrowing base equal to the aggregate of 80% of eligible accounts receivable, plus 50% of eligible
aircraft parts. The amount available under the Second Amended
Credit Agreement is also reduced by any outstanding letters of credit issued under the Second
Amended Credit Agreement. The Second Amended Credit Agreement bears interest, at AirNet&#146;s option,
at (a)&nbsp;a fixed rate equal to LIBOR plus a margin determined by AirNet&#146;s leverage ratio as defined
in the Second Amended Credit Agreement, or (b)&nbsp;a floating rate based on the greater of (i)&nbsp;the
prime rate established by The Huntington National Bank from time to time plus a margin determined
by AirNet&#146;s leverage ratio or (ii)&nbsp;the sum of 0.5% plus the federal funds rate in effect from time
to time plus a margin determined by AirNet&#146;s leverage ratio.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Second Amended Credit Agreement permits AirNet to maintain and incur other indebtedness in an
aggregate amount of up to $10.0&nbsp;million for the purpose of purchasing or refinancing aircraft and
related tangible fixed assets. The Second Amended Credit Agreement contains certain financial
covenants that require AirNet to maintain a minimum consolidated tangible net worth and to not
exceed certain fixed charge coverage and leverage ratios specified in the Second Amended Credit
Agreement. The Second Amended Credit Agreement also contains limitations on operating leases,
significant corporate changes including mergers and sales of assets, investments in subsidiaries
and acquisitions, liens, capital expenditures, transactions with affiliates, sales of accounts
receivable, sale and leaseback transactions and other off-balance sheet liabilities, contingent
obligations and hedging transactions.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Other Term Notes</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On March&nbsp;24, 2005, AirNet entered into a three-year term loan totaling $11.0&nbsp;million with a fixed
interest rate of 8.12%. This term loan is secured by seven Cessna Caravans and nine Learjet 35
aircraft from AirNet&#146;s cargo aircraft fleet. The aircraft securing this loan were released from
the collateral securing the loans under Amended Credit Agreement in accordance with the Second
Change in Terms Agreement. The proceeds from this term loan were used to prepay in full AirNet&#146;s
term loan under the Amended Credit Agreement as described above. As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, $8.0
million was outstanding under this term loan.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><I>Term Loans &#150; Discontinued Operations</I>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In connection with the closing of the sale of the Jetride passenger charter business on September
26, 2006, Jetride repaid in full six term loans which had been (a)&nbsp;secured by aircraft used in the
Jetride passenger charter business, and (b)&nbsp;guaranteed by AirNet. In June&nbsp;2004, Jetride entered
into four of the term loans, each with a seven-year term and a fixed interest rate of approximately
6.7%. In July&nbsp;2004, Jetride entered into the other two term loans, each with a seven-year term and
a fixed interest rate of approximately 6.5%. As of September&nbsp;26, 2006 and December&nbsp;31, 2005, there
was an aggregate principal amount of approximately $28.2&nbsp;million and $29.8&nbsp;million, respectively,
outstanding under the six loans. In addition to the outstanding principal amount, Jetride paid
approximately $0.3&nbsp;million in accrued interest and early termination prepayment penalties through
the repayment date. Each of the loan documents and corresponding security and guaranty agreements
entered into in connection with the six term loans was terminated upon repayment of the underlying
term loans at the closing.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Aggregate future maturities of long-term debt as of December&nbsp;31, 2006 are as follows:
</DIV>
<DIV align="center">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">AirNet also maintains standby letters of credit totaling $950,000 with a bank related to its
insurance policy agreements.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>5.&nbsp;Incentive Stock Plans</B>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On June&nbsp;4, 2004, the shareholders of AirNet Systems, Inc. approved the AirNet 2004 Stock Incentive
Plan (the &#147;2004 Plan&#148;), for employees of AirNet and its subsidiaries and non-employee directors of
AirNet. The 2004 Plan authorizes the granting of incentive and non-qualified stock options,
restricted stock, stock appreciation rights, and performance shares to be paid in common shares and
performance units to be paid in cash (collectively, &#147;2004 Plan Awards&#148;). In addition, the 2004
Plan provides for the granting of rights to purchase common shares of AirNet Systems, Inc. at up to
a 15% discount through payroll deductions by employees of AirNet and its subsidiaries (the &#147;2004
Stock Purchase Program&#148;). The maximum number
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->49<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>


<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>
<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">of common shares available for issuance under the 2004 Plan is 1,000,000. The 2004 Plan is
administered by the Compensation Committee of the Board of Directors, which determines the terms
and conditions applicable to the 2004 Plan Awards, other than non-qualified stock options
automatically granted to non-employee directors of AirNet Systems, Inc. in accordance with the
terms of the 2004 Program. The Compensation Committee also has the authority to establish
administrative rules and regulations regarding the term of each offering under the 2004 Stock
Purchase Plan. In July&nbsp;2005, non-qualified stock options covering 20,000 common shares were
automatically granted under the terms of the 2004 Plan to each of Messrs.&nbsp;Hellerman and Chadwick as
new Directors of AirNet. In December&nbsp;2006, non-qualified stock options covering 150,000 common
shares were granted to Bruce D. Parker, AirNet&#146;s Chief Executive Officer under the terms of an
employment contract. In 2006 and 2005, 16,547 and 23,414 common shares, respectively, were issued
under the 2004 Stock Purchase Program to employees of AirNet and its subsidiaries. The exercise
price of each option has been equal to the fair market price of a common share on the date of
grant. An option&#146;s maximum term is ten years. Option vesting periods range from vesting upon
grant to vesting over four years.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In 1996, AirNet Systems, Inc. adopted the AirNet Systems, Inc. 1996 Incentive Stock Plan (as
amended and restated, the &#147;1996 Plan&#148;). The 1996 Plan authorized the granting of incentive and
non-qualified stock options, restricted stock and performance awards (collectively, &#147;1996 Plan
Awards&#148;). In addition, the 1996 Plan provided for the granting of rights to purchase common shares
of AirNet Systems, Inc. at up to a 15% discount through payroll deductions by employees of AirNet
Systems, Inc. and its subsidiaries (the &#147;1996 Stock Purchase Program&#148;). The 1996 Plan also
provided for the grant of non-qualified stock options to non-employee directors of AirNet. The
maximum number of common shares available for issuance under the 1996 Plan is 1,650,000. The 1996
Plan is administered by the Compensation Committee of the Board of Directors, which determined the
terms and conditions applicable to the 1996 Plan Awards, other than non-qualified stock options
automatically granted to non-employee directors in accordance with the terms of the 1996 Plan. The
exercise price of each option has been equal to the fair market price of a common share on the date
of grant. An option&#146;s maximum term is ten years. Option vesting periods range from vesting upon
grant to vesting over four years. Since the adoption of the 2004 Plan, no additional 1996 Plan
Awards have been or will be made under the 1996 Plan.
</DIV>

option pricing model with the following weighted average assumptions for the years ended December
31:

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, the weighted average remaining contractual terms for

weighted average remaining contractual terms for options exercisable were 3.6&nbsp;years, 4.1&nbsp;years and

<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The following summarizes information about stock options outstanding (in thousands, except
remaining contractual life and price per share data) as of December&nbsp;31, 2006:
</DIV>
<DIV align="center">
<TABLE style="font-size: 10pt" cellspacing="0" border="0" cellpadding="0" width="100%">
<!-- Begin Table Head -->
<TR valign="bottom">
    <TD width="40%">&nbsp;</TD>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">AirNet&#146;s stock purchase program, which had been part of the 1996 Plan and is part of the 2004 Plan,
allows eligible employees the opportunity to acquire common shares of AirNet at up to a 15%
discount through payroll deductions. AirNet issued 16,547, 23,414, and 35,914 common shares
respectively during 2006, 2005, and 2004 from treasury shares under the stock purchase program.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>6. Lease Obligations</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">AirNet leases facility space and courier vehicles at various locations throughout the United
States. In January&nbsp;2002, AirNet entered into operating leases for six Cessna Caravan 208 aircraft,
which after certain extensions entered into in September&nbsp;2002, terminate in 2006 and 2007. In
January of 2003 and January of 2006, AirNet entered into two additional operating leases on Cessna
Caravan 208 aircraft that expire, respectively, in 2008 and 2007. In February&nbsp;2006, AirNet entered
into a one-year operating lease on an additional Cessna Caravan 208 aircraft.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In 2004, AirNet commenced construction of a new corporate and operational facility (the
&#147;Rickenbacker Facility&#148;) on land leased from the Columbus Regional Airport Authority (the
&#147;Authority&#148;). Construction of the Rickenbacker Facility was completed in May of 2005 and AirNet
completed the relocation of its flight and administrative operations to the Rickenbacker Facility
in June of 2005. The land lease with the Authority is for an initial term of 20&nbsp;years which
expires in May&nbsp;2025. AirNet may request two additional 10&nbsp;year extensions of the land lease. In
the event the Authority refuses to extend the land lease for either 10&nbsp;year extension period, the
land lease requires the Authority to purchase AirNet&#146;s leasehold improvements under the Federal
Relocation Act. The purchase price of the improvements cannot be less than 50% of the cost of the
leasehold improvements if the Authority refuses to extend the land lease for the first 10&nbsp;year
extension period and cannot be less than 25% of the cost of the leasehold improvements if the
Authority refuses to extend the land lease for the second 10&nbsp;year extension period. Annual rental
payments under the land lease are set at approximately $39,000, $62,000 and $83,000, respectively,
for the first three years of the lease term. Rental payments after the third year of the lease
term are subject to annual increases based upon the consumer price index.
</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">AirNet incurred lease expense of $2,455,000, $2,726,000, and $2,883,000 for the years ended
December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005 and 2004, respectively. As of December&nbsp;31, 2006, future minimum lease
payments by year under non-cancelable operating leases with initial or remaining terms exceeding
one year are as follows: 2007 &#151; $681,000; 2008 &#151; $143,000;
2009 &#151; $83,000; 2010 &#151; $83,000; 2011 -
$83,000.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Concurrently with the sale of AirNet&#146;s Port Columbus Facility in December&nbsp;2004, AirNet entered into
the New Port Columbus Lease. Pursuant to the New Port Columbus Lease, AirNet leased the real
property associated with the Port Columbus Facility and the buildings and all other improvements
thereon pending completion of the construction of AirNet&#146;s new office and hangar facility at
Rickenbacker. The term of the New Port Columbus Lease commenced on December&nbsp;15, 2004 and
terminated on August&nbsp;31, 2005. The New Port Columbus Lease was rent free until May&nbsp;15, 2005 and
commencing May&nbsp;16, 2005, the rent was scheduled to increase to $30,000 per month. The Authority
waived the scheduled rent increase for the period from May&nbsp;16, 2005 until the relocation of AirNet
to its new Rickenbacker Facility. The New Port Columbus Lease was a net lease under which AirNet
was responsible for all costs of operating the Port Columbus Facility. This transaction was a
minor sale-leaseback, as the present value of the rental payments was less than 10% of the
property&#146;s fair value; therefore, AirNet recorded a gain on the sale of $0.3&nbsp;million in 2004.
AirNet relocated from its Port Columbus Facility to the Rickenbacker Facility in June&nbsp;2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>7. Retirement Plan</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">AirNet has a 401(k) retirement savings plan. All associates who have completed a minimum of one
month of service may contribute up to 60% of their eligible annual earnings to the 401(k)
retirement savings plan, subject to the maximum
limitation imposed under the Internal Revenue Code. AirNet may elect, at its discretion, to make
matching and profit-sharing contributions. AirNet&#146;s contribution expense related to the 401(k)
retirement savings plan for continuing operations totaled $376,000, $358,000, and $492,000 for the
years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005, and 2004, respectively.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->51<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

    <TD colspan="7" align="left" style="border-top: 3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD colspan="7" align="left" style="border-top: 3px double #000000">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR>
<!-- End Table Body -->
</TABLE>
</DIV>


<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->52<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>

<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">State taxes, net of federal benefit, include a benefit of $158,000 in 2005 as a result of changes
in tax laws in the State of Ohio.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On December&nbsp;31, 2006, AirNet filed for a discretionary income tax method change with the Internal
Revenue Service (&#147;IRS&#148;). The discretionary method change requires IRS approval prior to the change
being effective. As required by SFAS No.&nbsp;109, the effect of the method change will be reported in
the period in which IRS approval is obtained; therefore, AirNet has not reflected the anticipated
impact of the method change in the December&nbsp;31, 2006 financial statements. There is no certainty as
to what extent or if the IRS will ultimately approve the elected method change as requested.
However, if the method change is approved, it could materially change AirNet&#146;s current taxes
payable, its deferred tax assets and the need for the associated valuation allowance and provide a
significant refund of estimated taxes previously paid.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In connection with the 1996 repurchase and cancellation of the Donald Wright Warrant, AirNet
recognized a related tax benefit estimated to be $7.0&nbsp;million based upon management&#146;s judgment and
estimation of the portion of the Donald Wright Warrant which would be deductible for income tax
purposes. This tax benefit was recognized as additional paid-in capital on AirNet&#146;s Consolidated
Balance Sheet and has had no effect on AirNet&#146;s Consolidated Statement of Operations. During the
third quarter of 2003, this matter was partially resolved and in the fourth quarter of 2006, was
finalized. AirNet has realized tax deductions related to this transaction in excess of
management&#146;s original estimates resulting in additional tax benefits. The additional tax benefits
associated with the deductible portion of the Donald Wright Warrant have exceeded the original
estimate by $1.3&nbsp;million in 2003 and $0.6&nbsp;million in 2006. The additional tax benefits, as was the
initial estimated tax benefit associated with the Donald Wright Warrant, have been recorded as an
increase to additional paid-in capital.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Accounting principles generally accepted in the United States require AirNet to record a valuation
allowance against future deferred tax assets if it is &#147;more likely than not&#148; that AirNet will not
be able to utilize such benefits in the future. At December&nbsp;31, 2006 and 2005, AirNet maintained a
valuation allowance of $12.5&nbsp;million and $6.3&nbsp;million, respectively. In 2006, the valuation
allowance offset deferred tax assets in excess of deferred tax liabilities. In 2005, the valuation
allowance offset AirNet&#146;s net operating loss carry forwards and Alternative Minimum Tax credit
carry forwards.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">For the years ended December&nbsp;31, 2006, 2005, and 2004, stock options covering 678,000, 553,000, and
686,000 common shares, respectively, were excluded from the diluted weighted average common shares
outstanding calculation, as their exercise prices exceeded the average fair market value of the
underlying common shares for the year and, therefore, were antidilutive.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>10. Litigation and Contingencies</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">AirNet is subject to claims and lawsuits in the ordinary course of its business. In the opinion of
management, the outcomes of these actions, which are not clearly determinable at the present time,
are either adequately covered by insurance, or if not insured, will not, in the aggregate, have a
material adverse impact upon AirNet&#146;s financial position or the results of future operations.
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->53<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>



<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In September&nbsp;2005, AirNet relocated its corporate and operational headquarters from 3939
International Gateway in Columbus, Ohio (the &#147;Port Columbus Facility&#148;) to its new facility at
Rickenbacker International Airport (the &#147;Rickenbacker Facility&#148;). AirNet&#146;s lease of its Port
Columbus Facility expired August&nbsp;31, 2005.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">AirNet also maintained certain assets at Port Columbus for dispensing aviation fuel under the terms
and conditions of a separate lease agreement (the &#147;Fuel Farm Lease&#148;). The Fuel Farm Lease required
AirNet to return the premises leased under the Fuel Farm Lease to their original condition upon the
termination of the lease. In lieu of returning the premises to their original condition, the Fuel
Farm Lease provided that the Port Columbus Airport Authority (the &#147;Authority&#148;) could take title to
any improvements constructed by AirNet on the leased premises. On August&nbsp;17, 2006, AirNet conveyed
all of its fuel farm assets to the Authority for $1 and a release of any future liabilities
associated with the Fuel Farm Lease and the fuel farm assets, other than any liabilities related to
environmental conditions which may be imposed by any governmental agency. The Fuel Farm Lease also
was terminated on August&nbsp;17, 2006. As a result of the conveyance of the fuel farm assets to the
Authority and the termination of the Fuel Farm Lease, AirNet was relieved of its obligation to
return the leased premises to their original condition.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Selected Quarterly Financial Information</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The quarterly financial data required to be disclosed in this Item&nbsp;8 is incorporated herein by
reference from the table captioned &#147;Selected Quarterly Data (Unaudited)&#148; in &#147;ITEM 7- MANAGEMENT&#146;S
DISCUSSION AND ANALYSIS OF FINANCIAL CONDITION AND RESULTS OF OPERATION&#148; of this Annual Report on
Form 10-K.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>ITEM 9A. CONTROLS AND PROCEDURES.</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Evaluation of Disclosure Controls and Procedures</B>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">With the participation of the Chairman of the Board, Chief Executive Officer and President (the
principal executive officer) and the Chief Financial Officer, Treasurer and Secretary (the
principal financial officer) of AirNet Systems, Inc. (&#147;AirNet&#148;), AirNet&#146;s management has evaluated
the effectiveness of AirNet&#146;s disclosure controls and procedures (as defined in Rule&nbsp;13a-15(e)
under the Securities Exchange Act of 1934, as amended (the &#147;Exchange Act&#148;)), as of the end of the
fiscal year covered by this Annual Report on Form 10-K. Based on that evaluation, AirNet&#146;s
Chairman of the Board, Chief Executive Officer and President and AirNet&#146;s Chief Financial Officer,
Treasurer and Secretary have concluded that:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="4%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>information required to be disclosed by AirNet in this Annual Report on Form 10-K
and the other reports that AirNet files or submits under the Exchange Act would be
accumulated and communicated to AirNet&#146;s management, including its principal executive
officer and principal financial officer, as appropriate to allow timely decisions
regarding required disclosure;</TD>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Changes in Internal Control over Financial Reporting</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">There were no changes in AirNet&#146;s internal control over financial reporting (as defined in Rule
13a-15(f) under the Exchange Act) that occurred during AirNet&#146;s fiscal quarter ended December&nbsp;31,
2006, that have materially affected, or are reasonably likely to materially affect, AirNet&#146;s
internal control over financial reporting.
</DIV>
<DIV align="left">
<A name="116"></A>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>ITEM 9B. OTHER INFORMATION</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt"><B>Conclusion of Brown Gibbons Lang &#038; Company Engagement and Dissolution of Strategy Committee</B>

</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">As previously reported by AirNet Systems, Inc. (&#147;AirNet&#148;), in January&nbsp;2005, AirNet engaged Brown
Gibbons Lang &#038; Company (&#147;BGL&#148;) to serve as AirNet&#146;s exclusive financial advisor and investment
banker to review, develop and evaluate various strategic alternatives to enhance shareholder value,
including the possible sale of AirNet. AirNet received indications of
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->54<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">interest with respect to the
sale of AirNet, which culminated in the execution of a letter of intent for the sale of AirNet on
October&nbsp;26, 2005. On December&nbsp;16, 2005, AirNet announced that it had been unable to reach a
definitive merger agreement with the private equity investment firm that entered into the letter of
intent and that the exclusivity period under such letter of intent had been allowed to expire.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Also as previously reported by AirNet, following the termination of the letter of intent, in
December of 2005, the AirNet Board of Directors dissolved the Special Committee which had been
established to oversee the marketing process and appointed a Strategy Committee to work with
management on the ongoing business strategy and alternatives for AirNet to enhance shareholder
value. The Strategy Committee, together with the full Board of Directors, determined that AirNet&#146;s
business strategy would include operating its businesses with an emphasis on cash flows from
operations while seeking other de-leveraging opportunities. The Board of Directors elected to
continue the engagement of BGL as its financial advisor on a month-to-month basis in connection
with the development and evaluation of various strategies and opportunities to enhance shareholder
value and de-leverage the business.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">As previously reported by AirNet, in September&nbsp;2006, AirNet sold its Jetride passenger charter
business. Thereafter, AirNet concluded its month-to-month engagement with BGL. However, AirNet
continues to consult with BGL from time-to-time on various strategies and opportunities to enhance
shareholder value. On February&nbsp;27, 2007, the Board of Directors dissolved the Strategy Committee.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Amendment of Credit Agreement with The Huntington National Bank</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On March&nbsp;29, 2007, AirNet and its lender (The Huntington National Bank) amended and restated the
terms and conditions of the Amended and Restated Credit Agreement dated as of May&nbsp;28, 2004, among
The Huntington National Bank and Bank One, N.A., as lenders, and AirNet, as borrower (as amended
and restated, the &#147;Amended Credit Agreement&#148;) by entering into a Second Amended and Restated Credit
Agreement (the &#147;Second Amended Credit Agreement&#148;). The following description of the Second Amended
Credit Agreement is qualified in its entirety by reference to the Second Amended Credit Agreement,
a copy of which is filed with this Annual Report on Form 10-K as
Exhibit&nbsp;4.50. The Second Amended
Credit Agreement provides for a $15.0&nbsp;million secured revolving credit facility and expires on
October&nbsp;15, 2008. The Second Amended Credit Agreement is secured by a first priority lien on all
of the property of AirNet, other than any interest in real estate and certain excluded fixed
assets. The stock and interests of AirNet&#146;s subsidiaries continue to be pledged to secure the
loans under the Second Amended Credit Agreement, and each of AirNet&#146;s subsidiaries continues to
guarantee AirNet&#146;s obligations under the Second Amended Credit Agreement under a Consent and
Agreement of Guarantors.
</DIV>



<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The amount of revolving loans available under the Second Amended Credit Agreement is limited to a
borrowing base equal to the aggregate of 80% of eligible accounts receivable, plus 50% of eligible
aircraft parts. The amount available under the Second Amended
Credit Agreement is also reduced by any outstanding letters of credit issued under the Second
Amended Credit Agreement. The Second Amended Credit Agreement bears interest, at AirNet&#146;s option,
at (a)&nbsp;a fixed rate equal to LIBOR plus a margin determined by AirNet&#146;s leverage ratio as defined
in the Second Amended Credit Agreement, or (b)&nbsp;a floating rate based on the greater of (i)&nbsp;the
prime rate established by The Huntington National Bank from time to time plus a margin determined
by AirNet&#146;s leverage ratio or (ii)&nbsp;the sum of 0.5% plus the federal funds rate in effect from time
to time, plus a margin determined by AirNet&#146;s leverage ratio.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Second Amended Credit Agreement permits AirNet to maintain and incur other indebtedness in an
aggregate amount of up to $10.0&nbsp;million for the purpose of purchasing or refinancing aircraft and
related tangible fixed assets. The Second Amended Credit Agreement contains certain financial
covenants that require AirNet to maintain a minimum consolidated tangible net worth and to not
exceed certain fixed charge coverage and leverage ratios specified in the Second Amended Credit
Agreement. The Second Amended Credit Agreement also contains limitations on operating leases,
significant corporate changes including mergers and sales of assets, investments in subsidiaries
and acquisitions, liens, capital expenditures, transactions with affiliates, sales of accounts
receivable, sale and leaseback transactions and other off-balance sheet liabilities, contingent
obligations and hedging transactions.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">As of March&nbsp;29, 2007, there were no amounts outstanding under either the Amended Credit Agreement
or under the Second Amended Credit Agreement, which replaced the Amended Credit Agreement. As of
March&nbsp;29, 2007, AirNet had approximately $1.0&nbsp;million in letters of credit outstanding related to
insurance programs, which reduced the amount available under the Second Amended Credit Agreement to
approximately $14&nbsp;million as of March&nbsp;29, 2007.
</DIV>




<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>2006 Incentive Compensation Plan</B>
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On March&nbsp;24, 2006, the Board of Directors of AirNet, upon the recommendation of the Compensation
Committee, adopted the 2006 Incentive Compensation Plan (the &#147;2006 Incentive Plan&#148;). The purpose
of the 2006 Incentive Plan was to
promote the following goals of AirNet for the fiscal year ended December&nbsp;31, 2006 (the 2006 fiscal
year&#148;) by providing incentive compensation to certain employees of AirNet and its subsidiaries:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

<TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="4%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Attaining designated levels of pre-tax income;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="4%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Improving cash flow and reducing debt;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="4%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Defining and executing plans to offset expected declines in Bank Services revenues;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="4%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Reducing the fixed cost structure of AirNet; and</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

    <TD width="4%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>Meeting high priority deadlines of AirNet.</TD>
</TR>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Participants in the 2006 Incentive Plan included the following individuals who served as executive
officers of AirNet during the 2006 fiscal year: Joel E. Biggerstaff (Chairman of the Board until
December&nbsp;31, 2006 and Chief Executive Officer and
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->55<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">President until December&nbsp;28, 2006), Gary W.
Qualmann (Chief Financial Officer, Treasurer and Secretary), Larry M. Glasscock, Jr. (Senior Vice
President, Express Services), Jeffery B. Harris (Senior Vice President, Bank Services), Ray L.
Druseikis (Controller and Principal Accounting Officer), and Craig A. Leach (Vice President,
Information Systems) &#151; as well as certain department managers and department directors. As of the
start of the 2006 fiscal year, there were 47 participants in the 2006 Incentive Plan. New
employees who qualified for the 2006 Incentive Plan were eligible to participate on the first day
of the calendar quarter following their date of hire. There were 46 participants who received
payments under the 2006 Incentive Plan, including Mr.&nbsp;Biggerstaff. There were also 32
non-participants who received discretionary awards totaling
approximately $75,000.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Payments under the 2006 Incentive Plan were based upon a combination of AirNet&#146;s pre-tax income (as
determined under the terms of the 2006 Incentive Plan) for the 2006 fiscal year, the operating
performance of AirNet&#146;s Delivery Services and Passenger Charter Services business segments, and the
achievement of personal goals assigned to each participant. The Compensation Committee approved the
personal goals for executive officers and reviewed the personal goals for other participants. The
personal goals approved by the Compensation Committee for each of the executive officers related to
specific business objectives related to general business operations (e.g., regulatory compliance,
expense reductions, etc.) and each business segment (e.g., execution of specific contracts with
customers and vendors, cost reductions, service improvements, etc.).
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">No incentive compensation was to be paid under the 2006 Incentive Plan unless AirNet achieved a
designated threshold level of pre-tax income for the 2006 fiscal year. If the designated threshold
level were achieved, incentive compensation payments would increase based upon predetermined
pre-tax income levels until a maximum aggregate amount of $1.9&nbsp;million in incentive compensation
payments was reached. After the overall amount of incentive compensation was determined based upon
AirNet&#146;s pre-tax income for the 2006 fiscal year, incentive compensation was allocated to
individual participants based upon the following four factors: (i)&nbsp;level of pre-tax income attained
by AirNet; (ii)&nbsp;level of contribution margin attained by Delivery Services as compared to certain
predetermined levels; (iii)&nbsp;levels of contribution margin attained by Passenger Charter Services as
compared to certain predetermined levels; and (iv)&nbsp;attainment of personal goals.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Originally, a participant&#146;s maximum incentive compensation payment was to range from 20% to 100% of
the participant&#146;s base salary, depending upon such participant&#146;s level of responsibility for
achieving AirNet&#146;s goals for the 2006 fiscal year. Twenty percent of each participant&#146;s incentive
compensation payments was to be based upon the participant&#146;s achievement of pre-established
personal goals. The remaining 80% of each participant&#146;s incentive compensation payment was to be
based upon a combination of the other three factors discussed above, which were allocated to each
participant based upon such participant&#146;s overall responsibility for attaining the designated
levels of AirNet&#146;s pre-tax income and contribution margins for the Delivery Services and Passenger
Charter Services business segments.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">In the event the incentive compensation payments otherwise available for payment under the 2006
Incentive Plan based upon AirNet&#146;s level of pre-tax income were not paid to certain participants as
a result of those participants&#146; failure to attain their personal goals or AirNet&#146;s failure to
attain the predetermined levels of budgeted contribution margins in Delivery Services or Passenger
Charter Services, such unpaid amounts could have been awarded at the discretion of the Compensation
Committee to participants in the 2006 Incentive Plan or to other employees of AirNet not
participating in the 2006 Incentive Plan.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Except for payments to the executive officers, payments under the 2006 Incentive Plan were paid in
quarterly payments commencing with the second quarter of the 2006 fiscal year based upon AirNet&#146;s
year-to-date financial performance. Except as described below with respect to Mr.&nbsp;Biggerstaff,
payments of incentive compensation to executive officers were made in March&nbsp;2007 based upon
AirNet&#146;s performance and each executive officer&#146;s performance for the 2006 fiscal year. Except as
described below with respect to Mr.&nbsp;Biggerstaff, in order to receive payment, a participant must
have been actively employed by AirNet at the time the payment was made.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On November&nbsp;8, 2006, the AirNet Board of Directors, upon the recommendation of the Compensation
Committee, adopted the following amendments to the 2006 Incentive Plan: (i)&nbsp;for purposes of
computing the pre-tax income of AirNet for the 2006 fiscal year for purposes of the 2006 Incentive
Plan, the $24.6&nbsp;million non-cash impairment charge recorded by AirNet in the third quarter of the
2006 fiscal year was to be disregarded and AirNet&#146;s pre-tax income for the 2006 fiscal year was to
be computed as if no impairment charge had been incurred; (ii)&nbsp;the incentive compensation payable
under the 2006 Incentive Plan to each of AirNet&#146;s officers, Joel E. Biggerstaff, Gary W. Qualmann,
Larry M. Glasscock, Jr., Jeffery B. Harris, Ray L. Druseikis and
Craig A. Leach, was to
be reduced to 60% of the amount each such officer would otherwise have been entitled to receive
under the 2006 Incentive Plan; (iii)&nbsp;for purposes of the 2006 Incentive Plan, the gain on the sale
of Jetride&#146;s passenger charter business was to be excluded from the computation of AirNet&#146;s pre-tax
income for the 2006 fiscal year; and (iv)&nbsp;Jetride&#146;s targeted pre-tax income for the fourth quarter
of 2006 was to be disregarded for purposes of the 2006 Incentive Plan and the predetermined pre-tax
income level at which the maximum incentive compensation payout would be reached under the 2006
Incentive Plan was to be reduced by a comparable amount.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">As previously reported, under the terms of the Separation Agreement and General Release, dated as
of December&nbsp;28, 2006 (the &#147;Separation Agreement&#148;), between AirNet and Mr.&nbsp;Biggerstaff, the
incentive compensation payable under the 2006 Incentive Plan to Mr.&nbsp;Biggerstaff was calculated
without regard to his personal goals for the 2006 fiscal year and, with respect
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->56<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>



<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">

<DIV align="left" style="margin-left: 0%; text-indent: 0%; margin-right: 0%; font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">to the financial
performance criteria, on an equitable basis with the other executive officers of AirNet. While
AirNet exceeded the level of pre-tax income at which the maximum incentive compensation payments
could be achieved, AirNet did not attain its pre-determined goal for contribution margin for
Passenger Charter Services. Accordingly, Mr.&nbsp;Biggerstaff was not entitled to the 20% of his
incentive compensation potential based upon the performance of AirNet&#146;s Passenger Charter Services
business. Mr.&nbsp;Biggerstaff was paid 60% of his remaining 80% incentive compensation potential, or
$156,000, after applying the 60% limitation described above.</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">After reviewing AirNet&#146;s pre-tax income, the operating performance of AirNet&#146;s various business
components and the level of achievement of the personal goals assigned to each executive officer,
at a meeting of the Compensation Committee held on February&nbsp;27, 2007, the Compensation Committee
asked Mr.&nbsp;Parker, AirNet&#146;s Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer, to recommend
additional discretionary awards to officers, other participants in the 2006 Incentive Plan, and
certain other employees who were not participants in the 2006 Incentive Compensation Plan. The
Compensation Committee met again on March&nbsp;5, 2007 and approved discretionary awards recommended by
Mr.&nbsp;Parker in the amount of $283,000. The amounts of such
discretionary awards were based upon the
contributions such officers, participants and other employees made to the operating performance of
AirNet during fiscal year 2006, as determined by Mr.&nbsp;Parker. Because of such discretionary
incentive compensation awards, the total incentive compensation payments made to certain executive
officers of AirNet exceeded the amounts that otherwise would have been paid given the 60%
limitation described above.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">During the 2006 fiscal year and the fiscal quarter ending March&nbsp;31, 2007, AirNet made payments
under the terms of the 2006 Incentive Plan in the aggregate amount of approximately $1.5&nbsp;million,
which included $156,000 paid to Mr.&nbsp;Biggerstaff as described above. In March of 2007, the
following executive officers of AirNet were paid the following amounts under the 2006 Incentive
Plan: Jeffery B. Harris- $160,000; Gary W. Qualmann &#151; $136,750; Larry M. Glasscock, Jr. &#151; $125,000;
Craig A. Leach &#151; $66,464; and Ray L. Druseikis -$46,550.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 12pt"><B>Adoption of 2007 Incentive Compensation Plan</B>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">On March&nbsp;28, 2007, the Board of Directors of AirNet, upon the recommendation of the Compensation
Committee, adopted the 2007 Incentive Compensation Plan (the &#147;2007 Incentive Plan&#148;). The purpose
of the 2007 Incentive Plan is to promote the following goals of
AirNet for the fiscal year ending December 31, 2007 (the &#147;2007
fiscal year&#148;) by providing incentive compensation to certain employees of AirNet:

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Participants in the 2007 Incentive Plan include AirNet&#146;s executive officers &#151; Bruce D. Parker
(Chairman of the Board and Chief Executive Officer), Gary W. Qualmann (Chief Financial Officer,
Treasurer and Secretary), Larry M. Glasscock, Jr. (Senior Vice President, Express Services),
Jeffery B. Harris (Senior Vice President, Bank Services), Ray L. Druseikis (Controller and
Principal Accounting Officer) and Craig A. Leach (Vice President,
Information Systems) and certain department managers and department directors.
As of the date of this Annual Report on Form 10-K, there were 37 participants in the 2007
Incentive Plan.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The targeted incentive compensation payment a participant may earn under the 2007 Incentive Plan
ranges from 20% to 100% of the participant&#146;s base salary, depending upon such participant&#146;s level of
responsibility for achieving AirNet&#146;s goals for the 2007 fiscal year. The targeted percentage of
annual base salary that each of AirNet&#146;s executive officers may earn as incentive compensation
under the 2007 Incentive Plan is as follows: Bruce D. Parker, 100%; Gary W. Qualmann, Larry M.
Glasscock, Jr., and Jeffery B. Harris, 75%; Ray L. Druseikis and Craig A. Leach, 50%.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Payments under the 2007 Incentive Plan will be based on a combination of AirNet&#146;s (i)&nbsp;pre-tax
income for the 2007 fiscal year, (ii)&nbsp;Express Services revenues and contribution margins for the
2007 fiscal year, and (iii)&nbsp;the achievement of personal goals assigned to each participant. The
Compensation Committee determines the personal goals of the Chief Executive Officer. The Chief
Executive Officer determines the personal goals for the other
executive officers, which are reviewed
and approved by the Compensation Committee. The personal goals of other participants are approved
by the Chief Executive Officer and are reviewed by the Compensation Committee. The personal goals
approved by the Compensation Committee for each of the executive officers relate to specific
business objectives related to general business operations (e.g., regulatory compliance, expense
reductions, etc.) and each business segment (e.g., execution of specific contracts with customers
and vendors, cost reductions, service improvements, etc.).
</DIV>

<P align="center" style="font-size: 10pt"><!-- Folio -->57<!-- /Folio -->
</DIV>

<!-- PAGEBREAK -->
<P><HR noshade><P>
<H5 align="left" style="page-break-before:always"><A HREF="#tocpage">Table of Contents</A></H5><P>


<DIV style="font-family: Helvetica,Arial,sans-serif">

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">With the
exception of Bruce D. Parker, no incentive compensation will be paid under the 2007 Incentive Plan unless AirNet achieves at
least 80% of its targeted pre-tax income for the 2007 fiscal year.
Mr. Parker will be eligible to receive the portion of his incentive
compensation potential allocated to his personal goals without regard
to AirNet&#146;s attainment of its financial objectives. Once this designated threshold
level of pre-tax income is achieved, potential incentive compensation payouts will increase at
predetermined levels until the maximum incentive compensation payout of approximately $1.7&nbsp;million
is reached at approximately 140% of AirNet&#146;s targeted pre-tax income for the 2007 fiscal year.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Once the aggregate potential incentive compensation payout is determined based upon the level of
pre-tax income achieved by AirNet during the 2007 fiscal year, each participant&#146;s incentive
compensation payment will be determined based upon the following three components of the 2007
Incentive Compensation Plan (i)&nbsp;pre-tax income for the 2007 fiscal year; (ii)&nbsp;Express Services
revenues and contribution margins for the 2007 fiscal year, and (iii)&nbsp;the achievement of personal
goals. With the exception of Mr.&nbsp;Parker, 20% of each participant&#146;s incentive compensation payout
is allocated to the attainment of personal goals. Forty percent of Mr.&nbsp;Parker&#146;s incentive
compensation payment is allocated to the attainment of personal goals. The portion of each
participant&#146;s incentive compensation potential that is not allocated to the attainment of personal
goals will be allocated to the attainment of predetermined levels of pre-tax income and Express
Services revenues and contribution margin based upon such participant&#146;s responsibility for
achieving such goals.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">No
incentive compensation will be earned with respect to the Express
Services component of the 2007 Incentive
Plan unless AirNet achieves at least 100% of its targeted Express Services revenues and
contribution margin. Once the designated threshold levels of Express Services revenues and
contribution margin are achieved, potential incentive compensation payouts under the Express
Services component of the 2007 Incentive Plan will increase at predetermined levels until the maximum
Express Services compensation payout level is achieved.
</DIV>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Mr.&nbsp;Parker&#146;s incentive compensation payments under the 2007 Incentive Plan will be based upon the
achievement of certain pre-determined financial objectives and
personal goals for the first
six months of the 2007 fiscal year and the last six months of the 2007 fiscal year. Mr.&nbsp;Parker
will be eligible to receive up to 50% of his annual base salary in
each six-month period, subject
to the attainment of Mr.&nbsp;Parker&#146;s predetermined financial
objectives and personal goals. In each six-month
incentive compensation period, Mr.&nbsp;Parker&#146;s incentive compensation potential will be allocated
among Mr.&nbsp;Parker&#146;s financial objectives and personal goals as follows:
</DIV>

<DIV style="margin-top: 6pt">
<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

    <TD width="4%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>30% of Mr.&nbsp;Parker&#146;s incentive compensation
potential will be based upon attaining at least 100%
of the targeted pre-tax income for the applicable six-month period;</TD>
</TR>

<TR>
    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>
</TR><TR valign="top" style="font-size: 10pt; color: #000000; background: transparent">
    <TD width="4%" style="background: transparent">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD width="2%" nowrap align="left"><B>&#149;</B></TD>
    <TD width="1%">&nbsp;</TD>
    <TD>30% of Mr.&nbsp;Parker&#146;s incentive compensation
potential will be based upon attaining at least 100%
of the targeted Express Services revenues and contribution margin for
the applicable six-month period; and</TD>

    <TD style="font-size: 6pt">&nbsp;</TD>

attainment of the personal goals established for Mr.&nbsp;Parker by the Board of Directors.</TD>

</TABLE>
</DIV>

year:

<TABLE width="100%" border="0" cellpadding="0" cellspacing="0" style="font-size: 10pt">

</TR>

<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">The Board of Directors will evaluate Mr.&nbsp;Parker&#146;s performance at the end of each six month
incentive compensation period and determine his incentive compensation payment based upon AirNet&#146;s
financial performance and achievement of Mr.&nbsp;Parker&#146;s personal goals during such period. In the
event the Board of Directors approves a strategic alternative that is completed based upon Mr.
Parker&#146;s efforts, Mr.&nbsp;Parker will be deemed to have met all his financial objectives and personal
goals for the six month incentive compensation period in which the strategic alternative is
completed. In such event, Mr.&nbsp;Parker will be entitled to receive his maximum incentive
compensation for such six month period, prorated from the first day of such six month period to the
date the strategic alternative is completed.
</DIV>


<DIV align="left" style="font-size: 10pt; margin-top: 6pt">Except for payments to Mr.&nbsp;Parker and AirNet&#146;s other executive officers, payments under the 2007
Incentive Plan will be paid in quarterly payments commencing with the first quarter of the 2007
fiscal year based upon AirNet&#146;s year to date financial performance. With the exception of Mr.
Parker, payments of incentive compensation to
</DIV>
